instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
board came in no liquid damage but does not boot.  it had a busted cap on ppbus which i replaced and now i have ppbus but no boot.

ppbus - 8.58v
pp3v42 - 3.42
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - .003v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.18v

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: What about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>  and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 2.018v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  - 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 2v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: Post <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> voltages; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
i noticed that <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was damaged (had a small hole in it) so i replaced it.
new voltages:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>  - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
23 - 8.58
12- 3.4
13 - 2
22- 3.3
29- 5
21- 3.4

still not getting fan spin

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> now?
Any voltage on other coils, apart of L7560?

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
i have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> now - 3.3v
i have no voltage on any large coils exepct l7560 and l7130

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  drops when i trigger smc onoff

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> should pulse at same time.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - its at 0v, but i get a pulse when smc onoff gets triggered

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
Then all S3 voltages must pulse too.
Also test if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> pulse at same time.
If yes, check S0 voltages.
Be sure no short on coils, nor behind power FETs (page 58).

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
i get a pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 
there are no shorts on large coils
i tested <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> and that pulses as well.
I will test the rest of s0 and s3 volatages as well as the fets

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: Don't forget to try SMC bypass...

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: with smc bypass i get fan spin for one second.  if i hit power button i get fanspin again for one second.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
i get pulse on
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - i have 2.1v.  I thought s0 only has power when unit is turned on, why am i getting stable 2.1v?  when i trigger i get 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - not getting pulse (diode mode on good board is .275, not working board is .215) maybe this is the issue line?
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - not getting pulse

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
Can you confirm voltage at L7430/60, or pulse at least?
What about pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
L7430  i don't have any voltage but i do get pulse with smc onoff triggered
L7460 - Not on schematic L7560? - 3.3v
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> i don't have any voltage but i do get pulse with smc onoff triggered on both 7 and 3

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
Sorry, I meant L7630.
If pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulses, then CPU core voltage must pulse too.
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message:
i get a very small pulse at L7630 with the trigger, but if i unplug and replug power i get power on the coil for about 1 second.
i get pulse on  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

i rechecked  <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> with plugging in and out and i do get power as well for one second.
i rechecked   <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> as well with plugging in and out and i do get power as well for one second.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: Check what happens removing <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: removed <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.  no fan spin. large coils still no voltage. what do you want me to check?

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: Is time to try known good BIOS.

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: pulled a <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> from a working board.  still no fanspin, no power on any coils and smc bypass only single fanspin then off

threads.title: 00165 no boot
threads.message: No luck, should be bad CPU...
